title: Erdős Problem #1114: Monotonicity of Critical Point Gaps
description: For a polynomial f with real roots in arithmetic progression, the gaps between consecutive critical points of f' increase outward from the midpoint.

overview.historicalContext: This was a conjecture of Erdős communicated personally to Bálint. Bálint proved it in 1960. Lorch (1976) gave generalizations to higher derivatives and other polynomial families.
overview.problemStatement: Let f(x) ∈ ℝ[x] be a polynomial of degree n whose roots form an arithmetic progression a₀ < a₁ < ... < aₙ. Then the gaps between consecutive critical points of f'(x), measured from the midpoint outward, are monotonically increasing.
overview.proofStrategy: The proof uses the special symmetry of polynomials with evenly spaced roots. By Rolle's theorem, f' has n critical points between the n+1 roots. The key insight involves convexity arguments showing that gaps increase away from the center.
keyInsights: By Rolle's theorem, f' has exactly n critical points in (a₀, aₙ)
The polynomial with AP roots has symmetry about its center
Critical points cluster toward the center, making outer gaps larger
Convexity of auxiliary functions establishes the monotonicity

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #1114 is SOLVED. Bálint (1960) proved that for polynomials with evenly spaced roots, the gaps between consecutive critical points increase as one moves from the midpoint toward the endpoints.
conclusion.implications: This result reveals structure in the critical points of polynomials with arithmetic progression roots. It connects root distribution to derivative behavior in a precise way.
openQuestions: Can the result be extended to polynomials with geometric progression roots?
What is the exact formula for the critical point locations?
Are there analogous results for complex roots?
